title: 14. The Histology of the Uterine Tubes

vectorData.altText: H12   The Histology of the Uterine Tubes

The wall of the uterine tube includes:
a mucosa with a simple columnar epithelium and a thick lamina propria (LP). The columnar epithelium includes two cell types:
ciliated cells (CC), which helps propel the luminal fluid toward the uterus, and
peg cells (PC), the glycoprotein secretions of which coat the luminal wall with mucous that supports the egg and sperm.
The epithelial cells respond to the cyclical secretions of the ovary. Estrogens secreted during the follicular phase promote cellular hypertrophy and ciliary elongation. Atrophy occurs as the end of the luteal phase nears.
a muscularis (M) with spiral and longitudinal muscle fibres. Wave-like contractions of the muscularis draws fluid through the tubes, toward the uterine lumen, thus promoting the transport of an ovum.
a serosa (S) forming a visceral peritoneum.
The mucosa possesses longitudinal folds which project into the lumen of the uterine tube.
The serosa (S) is composed of simple cuboidal epithelium (mesothelium) supported by CT.
